facts.text: This is a Criminal Appeal No. 80 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 80 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 17, 1967 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1210 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 17, 1967 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1210 of 1965. S.R. Chari, M. J. Mirchandani, K. K. Jain, H.

facts.text: Appellant and R. B. Mathur tried before Special Judge for Greater Bombay under various charges including conspiracy.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and one R. B. Mathur were tried before the learned Special Judge for Greater Bombay under various charges including a charge of conspiracy. Mathur was acquitted

facts.text: Mathur was acquitted and appeal against his acquittal was unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: Mathur was acquitted and the appeal against his acquittal was unsuccessful. The appellant was also acquitted of all charges excepting a charge under Section 5(2) read with

facts.text: Appellant convicted under Section 5(2) read with Section 5(1)(d) of Prevention of Corruption Act, sentenced to 2 years rigorous imprisonment and fine of Rs. 5000, default 4 months RI.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was also acquitted of all charges excepting a charge under Section 5(2) read with Section 5(1)(d) of the Prevention of Corruption Act. For that offence he was sentenced to suffer rigorous imprisonment for two years and pay a fine of Rs. 5,000, i.

facts.text: Appellant utilized position as Government servant to send articles like Radios, Transistors, Clothes from Goa to Bombay without paying customs duty.

anchor.surface_text: The substance of the charge under which he was convicted is that he by utilizing his position as a Government servant sent various articles such as Radios, Transistors, Clothes etc., from Goa to Bombay without paying customs duty. He was also held guilty of sending his personal articles in the vehicles engaged by the postal department without paying any charge.

facts.text: Appellant held guilty of sending personal articles in postal department vehicles without paying charge.

anchor.surface_text: He was also held guilty of sending his personal articles in the vehicles engaged by the postal department without paying any charge. The trial court supported its conclusion on a further ground namely that the assets of the appellant were more than that he could have acquired by his known sources of income.

facts.text: Trial court found appellant's assets more than known sources of income.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court supported its conclusion on a further ground namely that the assets of the appellant were more than that he could have acquired by his known sources of income. The charges framed against the appellant made reference to the fact that his assets were more than that he could have acquired by his known sources of income.

facts.text: High Court did not examine disproportionate assets aspect.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal the learned judges of the High Court did not go into that aspect of the case. Nor was that aspect of the case pressed before us at the hearing. Therefore it is not necessary to go into that aspect.

facts.text: Appellant sent goods in postal vehicles from Panjim in Goa to Margoa or Sawanthwadi or Belgaum.

anchor.surface_text: The accusation is that the appellant sent some of his goods in the vehicles engaged by the postal department from Panjim in Goa to Margoa or Sawanthwadi or Belgaum. These places are not very far from Panjim.

facts.text: High Court held postal vehicle misuse offence technical and trifling, did not examine.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the offence committed by the appellant in that regard if true, is of a technical nature and therefore it thought it unnecessary to examine the evidence relating to the same. Evidently in its view the accusation regarding the sending of some articles in the vehicles engaged by the postal department was of a trifling nature and therefore not worth examining.

facts.text: High Court agreed with trial court that appellant guilty of evading customs duty using official position.

anchor.surface_text: But the High Court agreed with the trial court that the appellant was guilty of evading payment of customs duty and he did so by utilizing his official position.

facts.text: In 1961, appellant working as Senior Superintendent of Post Offices at Jaipur.

anchor.surface_text: In 1961, the appellant was working as a Senior Superintendent of Post Offices at Jaipur. On December 20, 1961 Goa was liberated by the Indian Army.

facts.text: Goa liberated by Indian Army on December 20, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: On December 20, 1961 Goa was liberated by the Indian Army. Thereafter the appellant was deputed as a Special Duty Officer to Goa.

facts.text: Appellant took charge as Special Duty Officer in Goa on December 25, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the appellant was deputed as a Special Duty Officer to Goa. He took charge in Goa on December 25, 1961.

facts.text: Appellant assumed additional charge as Director of Posts and Telegraphs on May 11, 1962 till August 11, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: He assumed additional charge as Director of Posts and Telegraphs on May 11, 1962 and he held that office till August 11, 1962. Thereafter he went back to Jaipur.

facts.text: Appellant went back to Jaipur after August 11, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter he went back to Jaipur. It is alleged that during the period of appellants stay in Goa, he made large purchases of certain luxury articles.

facts.text: Twelfth amendment to Constitution received President's assent on March 27, 1962, made Goa Union Territory, deemed in force from December 20, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: As mentioned earlier Goa was liberated on December 20, 1961. Twelfth amendment to our Constitution which received the assent of the President on 27th March 1962 made Goa a part of India. It became a Union Territory. The amendment in question is deemed to have come into force on December 20, 1961.

facts.text: Goods complained of sent from Goa to Bombay after March 27, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: It may be noted that according to the prosecution the goods complained of were all sent from Goa to Bombay after March 27, 1962.

facts.text: No statute or rule showed customs duty imposed on goods from Goa to India after December 20, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: This takes us to the question whether there is any liability to pay customs duty when someone sent goods from Goa to Bombay in 1962. No statute or statutory rule was placed before the Court to show that any customs duty had been imposed on the goods transmitted from Goa to other parts of India after December 20, 1961.

facts.text: PW 56 Shaikh testified customs duty leviable due to administrative instructions but refused to produce them claiming privilege.

anchor.surface_text: The only witness who spoke about the liability to pay customs duties on the goods in question is P. W. 56 Shaikh, the Dy. Superintendent of Central Excise. According to him customs duty on those articles was leviable because of certain administrative instructions. But he refused to place those administrative instructions before the court. He claimed privilege on the ground that they are confidential documents a strange claim.

facts.text: Notification in 1950 declared Goa foreign territory under Land Customs Act.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that there was a notification issued in the year 1950 declaring Goa to be a foreign territory and thus bringing the exports from that country to India within the purview of Land Customs Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside conviction and sentence, appeal allowed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result this appeal is allowed and the conviction and sentence imposed on the appellant are set aside. He is on bail.

anchor.surface_text: This takes us to the question whether there is any liability to pay customs duty when someone sent goods from Goa to Bombay in 1962.

arguments.claim: Goa became part of India from December 20, 1961 via Twelfth Amendment deemed in force from that date

anchor.surface_text: As mentioned earlier Goa was liberated on December 20, 1961. Twelfth amendment to our Constitution which received the assent of the President on 27th March 1962 made Goa a part of India. It became a Union Territory. The amendment in question is deemed to have come into force on December 20, 1961.

arguments.claim: No statute or statutory rule imposed customs duty on goods from Goa to other parts of India after December 20, 1961

anchor.surface_text: This takes us to the question whether there is any liability to pay customs duty when someone sent goods from Goa to Bombay in 1962. No statute or statutory rule was placed before the Court to show that any customs duty had been imposed on the goods transmitted from Goa to other parts of India after December 20, 1961.

arguments.claim: Customs duty on goods not leviable based on administrative instructions as no tax without authority of law under Article 265

anchor.surface_text: The only witness who spoke about the liability to pay customs duties on the goods in question is P. W. 56 Shaikh, the Dy. Superintendent of Central Excise. According to him customs duty on those articles was leviable because of certain administrative instructions. But be refused to place those administrative instructions before the court. He claimed privilege on the ground that they are confidential documents a strange claim. Stranger still is that the trial court appears to have accepted that plea. No tax or duty can be levied or collected except by authority of law.

arguments.claim: 1950 notification declaring Goa foreign territory under Land Customs Act ceased to have effect after Goa became part of India

anchor.surface_text: It appears that there was a notification issued in the year 1950 declaring Goa to be a foreign territory and thus bringing the exports from that country to India within the purview of Land Customs Act. But that notification cannot continue to have a legal effect after Goa became a part of India.

arguments.claim: Section 5 of Indian Tariff Act 1934 empowered declaration of foreign territory only for territories outside India not parts of India

anchor.surface_text: That section read Where a customs duty at any rate prescribed by or under this Act or any other law for the time being in force is leviable on any articles when imported into, or any article when exported from, a port in India the Central Government may, by notification in the official gazette, direct that a duty of customs at the like rate shall be leviable on any such article when imported or exported, as the case may be, by land from or to any territory outside India which it may, by, a like notification, declare to be foreign territory for the purposes of this section.

arguments.court_reasoning: Practical considerations do not change the legal position

holdings.text: No statute or statutory rule imposed customs duty on goods transmitted from Goa to other parts of India after December 20, 1961, hence no liability to pay customs duty when sending goods from Goa to Bombay in 1962.

anchor.surface_text: No statute or statutory rule was placed before, the Court to show that any customs duty had been imposed on the goods transmitted from Goa to other parts of India after December 20, 1961. The only witness who spoke about the liability to pay customs duties on the goods in question is P. W. 56 Shaikh, the Dy. Superintendent of Central Excise. According to him customs duty on those articles was leviable because of certain administrative instructions. But be refused to place those administrative instructions before the court. He claimed privilege on the ground that they are confidential documents a strange claim.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of any statute or rule presented; prosecution witness relied on unproduced administrative instructions.

holdings.text: Goa must be considered as a part of India from December 20, 1961, indisputably from March 27, 1962, via Twelfth Amendment and Article 1(3)(c).

anchor.surface_text: Hence Goa must be considered as a part of India from December 20, 1961 and indisputably at any rate from March 27, 1962. Article 1 of our Constitution says India, that is Bharat, shall be a Union of States. The states and the territories thereof shall be as specified in the First Schedule. The territory of India shall comprise-  a  the territories of the States  b  the union territories specified in the First Schedule, and  c  such other territories as may be acquired. All the territories that this country may acquire in whatever manner become part of India in view of Article 1  3   c . Further in the case of Goa by means of 12th amendment to the Constitution, the same is included in the 1st Schedule. Therefore there is no room for the contention that Goa was not a part of India during the relevant time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Twelfth Amendment deemed in force from liberation date; Article 1 incorporates acquired territories and schedules Goa as Union Territory.

holdings.text: No tax or duty can be levied or collected except by authority of law under Article 265; hence no customs duty leviable on basis of administrative instructions.

anchor.surface_text: No tax or duty can be levied or collected except by authority of law. Hence no customs duty was leviable on the basis of any administrative instruction. Every levy of customs duty or any other tax must be sanctioned, by law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitutional mandate requires legislative authority; witness's administrative instructions privileged and insufficient.

holdings.text: 1950 notification declaring Goa foreign territory under Land Customs Act cannot continue to have legal effect after Goa became part of India.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that there was a notification issued in the year 1950 declaring Goa to be a foreign territory and thus bringing the exports from that country to India within the purview of Land Customs Act. But that notification cannot continue to have a legal effect after Goa became a part of India. On becoming a part of India Goa ceased to be a foreign territory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Goa's integration ends its foreign status, lapsing prior notifications treating it as foreign.

holdings.text: Section 5 of Indian Tariff Act, 1934 empowers declaration of foreign territory only for territories outside India, not parts of India.

anchor.surface_text: That section read Where a customs duty at any rate prescribed by or under this Act or any other law for the time being in force is leviable on any articles when imported into, or any article when exported from, a port in India the Central Government may, by notification in the official gazette, direct that a duty of customs at the like rate shall be leviable on any such article when imported or exported, as the case may be, by land from or to any territory outside India which it may, by, a like notification, declare to be foreign territory for the purposes of this section. The notification under this section could have been issued only in respect of any territory outside India and not in respect of any part of India. That provision empowered the Government to declare any territory outside India as a foreign territory for the purposes of that provision. That provision did not empower the Government to declare any part of India as a foreign territory. But it gave power to the Central Government not to treat any territory outside India as a foreign territory for the purposes of that provision. To illustrate the position, the Central Government could not have declared either Delhi or Bombay as a foreign territory but it could have treated Nepal or Bhutan as not a foreign territory for the purposes of that provision. Once Goa became part of India, the Government was incompetent to declare that territory as a foreign territory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation limits power to external territories; post-integration, no competence to declare Goa foreign.

holdings.text: Conclusion that appellant utilised official position to evade customs duty must fail as no duty payable.

anchor.surface_text: That being so, the conclusion that the appellant had utilised his official position to evade customs duty must fail. It is not necessary for us to consider whether after integration of Goa, the Government could have imposed any duty on the goods that were sent from Goa to other parts of India. Suffice it to say that our attention was not invited to any law imposing such duties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of duty liability undermines charge under Prevention of Corruption Act Section 5(1)(d).

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; conviction and sentence under Section 5(2) read with Section 5(1)(d) of Prevention of Corruption Act set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In the result this appeal is allowed and the conviction and sentence imposed on the appellant are set aside. He is on bail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge lacks legal basis due to no customs duty evasion offence.

anchor.surface_text: In the result this appeal is allowed and the companyviction and sentence imposed on the appellant are set aside. He is on bail.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; conviction and sentence set aside

edges.explanation: Holding h1 explicitly concludes no liability to pay customs duty on goods from Goa to other parts of India after December 20, 1961, directly addressing issue i1

anchor.surface_text: No statute or statutory rule was placed before, the Court to show that any customs duty had been imposed on the goods transmitted from Goa to other parts of India after December 20, 1961. The only witness who spoke about the liability to pay customs duties on the goods in question is P. W. 56 Shaikh, the Dy. Superintendent of Central Excise. According to him customs duty on those articles was leviable because of certain administrative instructions. But be refused to place those administrative instructions before the court. He claimed privilege on the ground that they are confidential documents a strange claim.
In the result this appeal is allowed and the companyviction and sentence imposed on the appellant are set aside. He is on bail.
mbercustom duty was leviable on the articles said to have been sent by the appellant from Goa to Bombay and as such the entire fabric of the prosecuti

edges.explanation: Goa part of India from Dec 20/March 27 supports no duty imposition after
Goa part of India from 1961/1962 supports h4 that Land Customs Act notification declaring it foreign cannot continue

anchor.surface_text: Hence Goa must be considered as a part of India from December 20, 1961 and indisputably at any rate from March 27, 1962. Article 1 of our Constitution says India, that is Bharat, shall be a Union of States. The states and the territories thereof shall be as specified in the First Schedule. The territory of India shall comprise-  a  the territories of the States  b  the union territories specified in the First Schedule, and  c  such other territories as may be acquired. All the territories that this country may acquire in whatever manner become part of India in view of Article 1  3   c . Further in the case of Goa by means of 12th amendment to the Constitution, the same is included in the 1st Schedule. Therefore there is no room for the contention that Goa was not a part of India during the relevant time.
In the result this appeal is allowed and the companyviction and sentence imposed on the appellant are set aside. He is on bail.

edges.explanation: Article 265 requires authority of law for tax/duty, no levy on administrative instructions, supports h1 no liability to customs duty
No duty leviable without authority of law (Article 265) addresses issue i1 of liability to customs duty

anchor.surface_text: No tax or duty can be levied or collected except by authority of law. Hence no customs duty was leviable on the basis of any administrative instruction. Every levy of customs duty or any other tax must be sanctioned, by law.
In the result this appeal is allowed and the companyviction and sentence imposed on the appellant are set aside. He is on bail.
at plea. No tax or duty can be levied or companylected except by authority of law. Hence numbercustoms du

edges.explanation: Holding h4 states 1950 notification declaring Goa foreign territory under Land Customs Act cannot continue to have legal effect after Goa became part of India, undercutting prior applicability of c6
Invalidity of Land Customs Act notification post-Goa integration supports h1 no liability to customs duty

anchor.surface_text: It appears that there was a notification issued in the year 1950 declaring Goa to be a foreign territory and thus bringing the exports from that country to India within the purview of Land Customs Act. But that notification cannot continue to have a legal effect after Goa became a part of India. On becoming a part of India Goa ceased to be a foreign territory.
In the result this appeal is allowed and the companyviction and sentence imposed on the appellant are set aside. He is on bail.

edges.explanation: Section 5 Indian Tariff Act empowers foreign territory declaration only outside India supports h1 no duty liability post-integration
Power to declare foreign territory limited to territories outside India supports h4 invalidity of notification after Goa integration

anchor.surface_text: That section read Where a customs duty at any rate prescribed by or under this Act or any other law for the time being in force is leviable on any articles when imported into, or any article when exported from, a port in India the Central Government may, by notification in the official gazette, direct that a duty of customs at the like rate shall be leviable on any such article when imported or exported, as the case may be, by land from or to any territory outside India which it may, by, a like notification, declare to be foreign territory for the purposes of this section. The notification under this section could have been issued only in respect of any territory outside India and not in respect of any part of India. That provision empowered the Government to declare any territory outside India as a foreign territory for the purposes of that provision. That provision did not empower the Government to declare any part of India as a foreign territory. But it gave power to the Central Government not to treat any territory outside India as a foreign territory for the purposes of that provision. To illustrate the position, the Central Government could not have declared either Delhi or Bombay as a foreign territory but it could have treated Nepal or Bhutan as not a foreign territory for the purposes of that provision. Once Goa became part of India, the Government was incompetent to declare that territory as a foreign territory.
In the result this appeal is allowed and the companyviction and sentence imposed on the appellant are set aside. He is on bail.
a, the Government companyld have imposed any duty on the goods that were sent from Goa to other parts of India. Suffice it to say that our attention w

edges.explanation: Holding that utilization to evade duty fails as no duty payable undercuts the POCA conclusion
No duty payable addresses issue i1 by negating evasion premise tied to liability

anchor.surface_text: That being so, the conclusion that the appellant had utilised his official position to evade customs duty must fail. It is not necessary for us to consider whether after integration of Goa, the Government could have imposed any duty on the goods that were sent from Goa to other parts of India. Suffice it to say that our attention was not invited to any law imposing such duties.
In the result this appeal is allowed and the companyviction and sentence imposed on the appellant are set aside. He is on bail.
